f6_assessments.q0: This proposal contains no other information besides the three mandatory fields, and while the very brief problem statement presents a problem that could fit well in this category, the solution to the problem is too generalised. The lack of a plan, or any other details leave the proposal in an inception state where it cannot be assessed properly.
f6_assessments.q1: The short, mandatory relevant experience field wasn't even filled with a brief description of the proposer's past experience. There is no other information in the proposal, no budget, no KPIs, or roadmap that could help in its assessment, making it impossible to say whether this project can be successfully completed.
f6_assessments.q2: As mentioned in the above assessments, the proposal is still in a draft stage, if resubmitted with the needed additional information, only then could it be properly evaluated.

f6_assessments.q0:
The identified problem is described in a vague manner, as "get informed" doesn't have any desired impact. The proposal needs to give a good insight on the identified problem (i.e.: people cannot get informed about implementation of new features developed for the ADA payment system etc.)

The solution must address the identified problem (i.e.: organizing virtual or on-site meetings local/national to present the latest news about the ADA payment system etc. - also the target audience should be identified - and speakers, if necessary).
The proposal is poorly presented and it needs a lot of rework for a better chance to get funded.
f6_assessments.q1:
The budget needs to be broken down into identifiable items (how much is estimated to spend for the resources that are going to be used - humans, stationery, apps etc.).
A roadmap with achievable milestones should be defined (1 week: team assembling (no. of members, roles, experience etc.), 2 weeks: meeting environment setup etc.).
The proposer has to consider challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: Because no relevant information was provided there is nothing to assess to this proposal.

It actually does not propose anything significant or substantial. This indicates that the proposer either has not read the challenge properly or does not fully grasp it. Feedback: I suggest for future proposals, you read up on the topic of the challenge and try to think about how your proposal can adress concrete points of this challenge. Hence, the proposal also does not explain how it adds value to the Cardano ecosystem.
The proposal has no key metrics and goals presented, so it cannot be told that it aligns with the challenge. Also, nothing is presented that can be said to be scalable. General feedback: Please think about what exactly you want to achieve and try formulating it in a structured, complete manner, so everyone can understand what is actually happening to the funds.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer does not provide sufficient information about themselves and does not provide proof of any relevant qualifications. Feedback: For future proposals, maybe consider linking some verifiable personal information about yourself or some of the work you have already done. The proposer does not seem to have a clear idea about the type and number of team members required to implement the proposal, in case there is a clearer plan that is not formulated here.
The budget set for this proposal does not have any justification or diversified items. Feedback: For future proposals, try to draft an accurate plan on what each item of your proposal will cost and rationable calculations on how you justify those costs. The proposal does not explain anything about implementation, challenges or risks. In general, it is not thought until the end and needs a basic step by step plan, defined requirements and a diversified budget to be considered feasible.

f6_assessments.q0: Great effort and passion from the proposer though based on their statement a solution is already available. Though it is unclear the intent of mentioning ADA and COTI. If the mentioning of ADA is in the context of cryptocurrency then there is a misunderstanding. For in the Cardano ecosystem we do not focus on price, rather on what and how can we be build on Cardano. If the proposer or investor seeks information regarding this, one can find the monthly Cardano360 or the weekly Town Halls in IOHK's official YouTube channel. There is also IOHK's regularly updated blogs in their website. For an informal setting, one can learn more on Cardano through Charles Hoskinson's (Cardano's founder) AMA and various other discussion on his YouTube channel. Regarding COTI, COTI is a different entity from Cardano or ADA , although they have a specific Challenge on Project Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q1: There is a conscious effort to try develop Cardano but unfortunately the proposer has not been exposed to the proper methods of submitting a proposal. It is most likely this proposal will not achieve it's intent. Perhaps the proposer needs to be more involved in the community. Highly recommend to start by watching the weekly Town Hall's and joining the Discord channel of Project Catalyst. Perhaps from there, the proposer then can learn from Catalyst School on the method and concept of submitting a proposal in Project Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q2: Again, perhaps this is due to lack of involvement in the community therefore not understanding the process of submitting a proposal in Project Catalyst. Passion is truly there but the proposer needs to take small steps (as mentioned above) first before applying to Project Catalyst. A+ for effort but unfortunately the information provided makes this proposal very challenging to audit.
